"RANAVIRU REAL STAR" COMPETITION : PARTICIPATION OF POLICE OFFICIALS 4787/14 1. ( ) (The Hon. Ashok Abeysinghe) - (2) :
() , ? asked the Minister of Public Order and Christian Religious Affairs:
(i) whether he accepts the fact that the Police officials and the Special Task Force of the Police too, made their contributions in concluding the war; and
(ii) if so, whether they have been recognized as War Heroes?

(b) Will he inform this House of the reasons that led not to permit the Police officials to take part in the competition "Ranaviru Real Star" which is organized with the intention of encouraging the War Heroes?
( ) ( - ) (The Hon. John Amaratunga - Minister of Public Order and Christian Religious Affairs) , .
( ) (The Hon. Ashok Abeysinghe) , . . . , . , , . . ( ) (The Hon. John Amaratunga) . . . . , . ( ) (Mr. Speaker) , .
: : SEALING OF STOCK OF CONSUMER ITEMS BY POLICE : DETAILS 5919/15 5. ( ) (The Hon. Susantha Punchinilame) - (1) :
asked the Minister of Public Order and Christian Religious Affairs:

(a) Will he state, separately, as to why and following whose complaint and order, the remainder from a stock of goods that had been purchased out of personal funds and distributed among the public as flood aid, and had been kept stored in an election operations office that was run at No.49/1, Samanala Mawatha, Kandy Road, China Bay, during the last Presidential Election period, was sealed by the police on a court order and was referred to courts for initiating legal proceedings?
(i) whether the Police Department will take the responsibility for the damage that could be caused to those goods as a bulk, as most of the goods sealed are consumer items;

(ii) the basis on which the driver who was taking the Double Cab that was parked at that office premises on the same day, bearing No. WP PA-4549 belonging to the then Ministry of Economic Development, was arrested and the persons who made the complaint; and
(iii) whether steps will be taken to prevent the recurrence of such arbitrary incidents as mentioned above in future?
(c) If not, why? ( ) (The Hon. John Amaratunga) , .

( ) (The Hon. John Amaratunga) , . ( ) (The Hon. Susantha Punchinilame) . : : HORANA DS DIVISION : IMPLEMENTATION OF DRINKING WATER PROJECTS 5922/15 6. ( ) (The Hon. Vidura Wickramanayaka) - (1) :
asked the Minister of Provincial Councils and Regional Development:

(a) Is he aware that the approved projects of the National Water Supply and Drainage Board for the provision of drinking water cannot be implemented as a result of permission not being granted by the Western Province Road Development Authority to break the shoulder of the road from Horana to Labugama Junction via Hegalla, the road from Sawgashandiya, Horana to Thalgahawila up to Kuda Uduwa, the road from Kulupana, Horan to Mawgama up to Olaboduwa and the road from Horana to Uduwa via Ovitiyagala, Henkanda in the Divisional Secretary's Division of Horana?

(b) Will he state whether action will be taken to grant permission to break the shoulders causing minimum damage to the above-mentioned roads, which had been carpeted more than five years ago, in order to implement the drinking water projects for the people of the said areas?

: / : / WILDLIFE CONSERVATION DEPARTMENT: ELEPHANTS KEPT WITH/WITHOUT PERMITS
() , ? asked the Minister of Tourism and Sports:

(a) Is he aware that there is a programme that media maliciously publish incidents of keeping elephants even before the Wildlife Conservation Department search the places where the elephants are kept with or without permits and verify the authenticity of the permits and take the suspects into custody?
(i) the number of elephants-tuskers with permits that were taken into custody after the previous Presidential election;
(ii) the names, addresses and the telephone numbers of the aforesaid permit holders;
(iii) the number of elephants-tuskers reared without permits that were taken into custody during the aforesaid period of time;
(iv) the names, addresses and the telephone numbers of the persons who kept the elephants-tuskers without permits;
(v) the places where such elephants-tuskers who have been taken into custody have been kept;
(vii) whether the elephants-tuskers that should be handed over legally have been identified; and
(viii) if so, the date on which they will be handed over?
(b) If not, why? ( ) ( - ) (The Hon. Vasantha Senanayake - Deputy Minister of Tourism and Sports) , .

: : CULTURAL OFFICERS AND CULTURAL DEVELOPMENT ASSISTANTS : DETAILS
() , ? asked the Prime Minister and Minister of Policy Planning, Economic Affairs, Child, Youth and Cultural Affairs:
(i) the total number of Cultural Officers and Cultural Development Assistants employed in Divisional Secretariats and District Secretariats at present;
(ii) whether the aforesaid officers are entitled to the promotions that the other officers of the Public Service are entitled to;
(iii) if so, of the service conditions applicable to granting the aforementioned promotions;
(iv) if promotions are not applicable, whether the post held by the aforesaid officers at the time of their retirement would be the same as the designation held by them at present;
(v) whether Cabinet approval for granting promotions to the aforesaid officers had been granted before this;
(vi) if so, of the reasons for not implementing the aforementioned approval; and
(vii) whether Assistant Cultural Officer positions have been abolished by now under Public Administration Circular No. 6/2006?
( ) ( - ) (The Hon. Nandimithra Ekanayake - State Minister of Culture) , , , , .
( ) (The Hon. Nandimithra Ekanayake) , . . . . : : ROAD DEVELOPMENT PROJECTS : MONEY GRANTED BY LOCAL BANKS
() , ? asked the Prime Minister and Minister of Policy Planning, Economic Affairs, Child, Youth and Cultural Affairs:
(a) Will he state whether money is granted by local banks for road development?
(i) the names of local banks which have granted money for road development projects; and
(ii) separately, the amount of money granted by each of the said banks and the road projects for which money has been granted?
(c) Will he inform this House of the method of recovering of the money thus granted?
(d) If not, why? ( ) (The Hon. Ranil Wickremasinghe) , .

(a) Will he inform this House separately the number of -
(ii) coordinating centres which operated for coordinating the aforesaid centers;
(vi) for conducting the GCE (Ordinary Level) examination held in the year 2013?
(b) Will he table separately, the names, addresses and telephone numbers of the hall assistants mentioned in (a)(v) above?
(i) the number of employees who are related to the field of education and the number of employees who are not related to that field out of the aforesaid hall assistants separately; and
(ii) the amount paid as salaries and allowances for the hall assistants who were recruited from outside for the duties of the aforesaid examination?

(ii) if so, the manner in which it will be done?
(e) If not, why? ( ) ( - ) (The Hon. Akila Viraj Kariyawasam - Minister of Education) , * .
5436/14 3. ( ) ( - ) (The Hon. Ashok Abeysinghe on behalf of the Hon. Ajith Mannapperuma) - (2) :
() , ? asked the Minister of Power and Energy:
(a) Will he state the percentage of Sulphur that contains in the diesel that was imported for the storage tanks complex of the Muthurajawela Ceylon Petroleum Storage Terminals Ltd?
(i) separately, the sulphur percentage that contains in Lanka Auto diesel and super diesel, that is available for sale in the filling stations of Gampaha District; and
(ii) the fuel storage terminal by which Auto diesel and Super diesel is provided for the filling stations of Gampaha District?
(c) If not, why? ( ) ( - ) (The Hon. Palitha Range Bandara - State Minister of Power and Energy) , * .
: : UNAUTHORIZED CONSTRUCTION ON PUBLIC LAVATORY SYSTEM: COLOMBO MUNICIPAL COUNCIL AREA
() , ? asked the Minister of Public Administration, Local Government and Democratic Governance:

(a) Is he aware that there is an unauthorized construction on the urban public lavatory system obstructing the access road to the places bearing assessment numbers 108 and 108/20 in Ven. Hikkaduwa Sri Sumangala Mawatha, in the Kuppiyawatta West Division, No. 32 of the Colombo Municipal Council area?

(b) Will he inform this House whether action will be taken forthwith to remove those constructions since the public lavatory system has become a personal property due to the unauthorized constructions built with the support of the certain officers in the Colombo Municipal Council?
2014 : 2014 : BUDGET PROPOSALS 2014 : INCENTIVES 4999/14 9. ( ) ( - ) (The Hon. Ashok Abeysinghe on behalf of the Hon. Buddhika Pathirana) - (1) :
() , ? asked the Minister of Home Affairs:

(i) whether the proposal of the 2014 Budget to grant incentives of Rs. 15,000/- and Rs. 5,000/- respectively to District Secretaries and Divisional Secretaries and Rs. 3,000/- for Planning Directors and Chief Accountants attached to District Secretariats has been fulfilled by now; and
(ii) if so, the date on which such payments commenced?
(i) the reason for proposing an incentive of a lower value for Planning Directors and Chief Accountants attached to District Secretariats;
(ii) whether he admits that the service of the officials mentioned in (i) above has been underestimated as a result of the decision to pay a lower incentive;
(iii) if so, whether action will be taken to increase their incentives;
(iv) the amount of such increase; and
(v) the date on which such an increase will be carried out?
. ( ) ( . - ) (The Hon. M. Joseph Michael Perera - Minister of Home Affairs) , * .
( ) ( - ) (The Hon. Lakshman Kiriella - Minister of Plantation Industries and Leader of the House of Parliament) , .

. , . . . , . . , . ( ) (Mr. Speaker) Yes, Hon. (Prof.) Rajiva Wijesinha. () ( () ) (The Hon. (Prof.) Rajiva Wijesinha) Hon. Speaker, having read the Report of the Committee, I think it is absolutely essential that this be debated thoroughly in Parliament. It makes some very startling comments and, in fact, suggests the need for much further inquiry and specifically states, "... there is no impediment for the Government and or Parliament and or any Organization with public interest to engage in necessary mechanism in establishing the loss to the Government ...". I do not think it is an adequate Report but, at least, it has not attempted a complete whitewash. Given its recommendations, I would have thought that any responsible Government anxious to oppose corruption as this Government claims it is, would have immediately instituted the investigations that are recommended even by their own Report. So, I find it absolutely sad that so much time has passed without the necessary action being taken.

As you know, Mr. Speaker, several of us wanted a change and we wanted a change so that the victories of 2009 would be strengthened but, in a pluralistic fashion that there would be less authoritarianism; that there would be less corruption but that development would continue. And, as you can see from the Manifesto of His Excellency the President, there are many pledges which remain to be fulfilled.
Sir, I do not know whether "Hiru TV" cited the Hon. Prime Minister wrong but it seemed to indicate that he

said, "We no longer have a programme; there should not be a Government; it is time for an election". That may have been a mistake and I think there is a lot of work to be done. Unfortunately, the strengthening of the victory of 2009 and the development seems to have stopped; the corruption and the authoritarianism are continuing but in a much more sophisticated fashion that was started by the first Executive President of this country. I am afraid that tradition is something that we must stop. The way to stop it is through strengthening Parliament .

I listened with interest to your Ruling yesterday but I also think, Hon. Speaker, that you must take cognizance of the fact that hardly any Committees of Parliament are functioning. I got a schedule yesterday from the Committee Office and despite the pledge in His Excellencys Manifesto to strengthen the committee system, only four meetings of Consultative Committees have been held over the last 125 days. This is appalling. It has never happened in a Sri Lankan Parliament before; the consultation of Members of Parliament has never been treated with such contempt.

I had the sad occasion yesterday of attending the Consultative Committee on Education where, what the officials said about the Bill to be presented today, was completely wrong. The Secretary said that the Bill to abolish the NATE arose because the NATE had been established for teacher education and then the NIE was established, and because they were in opposition to each other, this had to be got rid of. As you know, I have been engaged in education for the last 30 years and I do think there is no collective memory in the Ministry. Let me be complimentary. The Hon. Prime Minister in one successful effort of his political career was a good Minister of Education. - [Interruption.] I am talking. Let me finish, please.

( ) (The Hon. Mahindananda Aluthgamage) . () ( () ) (The Hon. (Prof.) Rajiva Wijesinha) Hon. Speaker, I am talking about the fact that the Consultative Committees had not met. When we met yesterday, we were completely misled. The Hon. Minister had the grace to say that neither he nor his secretary knew anything about the subject. But, if you are the Minister, you must learn about it. You cannot come there and say that you know nothing when a Bill is being presented. If the Consultative Committees are not meeting, Sir, - while I can see the point of your Ruling yesterday, - you must ensure that these Committees meet.
The COPE has not met for four months. So, Hon. Speaker, I think a two-pronged approach is necessary: firstly, an immediate discussion of this absolutely-

startling document, even though it was not of a Select Committee but a report of UNP lawyers; secondly, on the Motion put forward with regard to the Governor of the Central Bank, the poor man maybe a fall guy for more subtle forces making money but that too should be debated. Please ensure that the committees you have suggested meet immediately and present a report to Parliament, so that it can be debated on the 9th of June.
[At this stage, some Members of the Opposition rose from their seats.]

Hon. Speaker, I think the reference made by the Hon. (Prof.) G.L. Peiris was in regard to this Report and the Treasury Bond issue, which I said, should be discussed in the House. I think the Hon. (Prof.) Rajiva Wijesinha confused this with the National Authority on Teacher Education (Repeal) Bill that was presented. I have no intention of referring to anything about that Bill, but I must say that only recently the Consultative Committees were appointed and, I did assure this House, that I would summon the Consultative Committee on my Ministry to discuss this Report, in addition to whatever directive the Hon. Speaker has given. Yesterday, he had asked the Committee on Public Enterprises to go into it. Similarly, before referring to the issues that the Hon. Bandula
Gunawardane raised, I would like to say that, as far as this Committee is concerned, the officials have found that the Bank has said that there had been no loss to the Treasury .

( ) (The Hon. Nimal Siripala de Silva) , , . . If you are genuine, please agree at the Supreme Court to pay this saying that this is your repayment plan. So, what we want is for you to ensure that what you say here is put into a legal bond before the Supreme Court without pressurizing the depositors to withdraw the case.
( ) (The Hon. Ravi Karunanayake) Hon. Leader of the Opposition, , . 91 . 12 . . 20 , 100 , . , . , - [ ]

( ) (The Hon. Nimal Siripala de Silva) ? ( ) (The Hon. Ravi Karunanayake) . , . - [ ] If required, we will give it in writing to the Court accepting that, because Chief Justice K. Sripavan had mentioned, That is a very fair settlement. Please go ahead with it. What was expected was a letter from us. But, the Attorney-General told us to give that letter at the time when consent would be given to withdraw the cases, because previously, 29 cases were to be withdrawn and they later duped; they had told one thing and did another. So, that was the instruction we have been given by the lawyers from the Attorney-Generals Department. - [Interruption.] We have no problem at all. As a matter of fact, after the depositors -
( ) (The Hon. Nimal Siripala de Silva) What you mentioned here in this House will be a part of the settlement in the Supreme Court. Is it?

( ) (The Hon. Ravi Karunanayake) Absolutely! It is not necessary even to say it in Parliament. As we said at the Ministry of Finance one week ago, it was legal from then, because our President and the Prime Minister gave us instructions and I am complying with the Government requirement. It was not a fanciful voyage of discovery by me. So, as you quite rightly said, I will even take the recommendation you gave and give it in writing to the Court that this is the repayment plan. Is that okay, Hon. Leader of the Opposition?

2015 2015 REPORT OF THE COMMITTEE TO LOOK INTO THE BOND ISSUES OF THE CENTRAL BANK 2015

"In terms of Standing Order 17(2), we give notice of a Motion for the Adjournment of Parliament, for the purpose of an urgent Debate on the Report of the Prime Minister's Panel of three lawyers on the Central Bank Bond issue, submitted to Parliament on Tuesday, 19th May by the Hon. Leader of the House.

We urge that the Debate takes place immediately because of the continuing and aggravating loss to the nation, for the mitigation of which Parliament is under a duty to act in furtherance of its responsibility for public finance under Article 148 of the Constitution.
We would also point out that the Hon. Prime Minister gave the assurance on the Floor of the House that the Report would be fully debated in Parliament, once the Report is submitted."

, . .. . Dr. G. Usvattearachchi, Dr. A.C. Visvalingam and Mr. Chandra Jayaratne . . .. , . . . I shall read it. Sir, the article captioned, "Supreme Court dismisses FR case against Treasury Bond fiasco" in the "Daily FT" of 14th May, 2015 states, I quote:

The petitioners though instructed by court to show any illegality or irregularity on the bids by Perpetual or the auction, were unable to point to any violation of the rules or statutes governing the issue of bonds

However, it was submitted by the counsel for Perpetual, with facts and figures obtained from the Central Bank, that out of the six 30-year bond auctions, this particular bond auction came at the lowest cost to the Government, ...
() . . ( () .. ) (The Hon. (Prof.) G.L. Peiris) What are you reading from?

( ) (The Hon. Lakshman Kiriella) This is the judgment. This is what I say. . This is part of the judgment - [Interruption.] They refused because the petitioners could not prove a single thing they averred in the petition. [Interruption.] Why? The petitioners, Dr. G. Usvattearachchi, Dr. A.C. Visvalingam and Mr. Chandra Jayaratne, were asked to point out any irregularity, they could not; they were asked to point out any illegality, they could not; they were asked to point out a loss, they could not.

So, this is what happened in the Supreme Court. You are doing the same thing that they did. They were making wild allegations and the Supreme Court said, Prove the allegations, but they could not. You read the judgment.
